description: In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): transmissible by direct or indirect contact with an infected person (describes the disease or the virus, not a person).
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): known cases of people who currently have the disease.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): cases of people infected with the virus which have been confirmed via medical testing.

Short for "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention": a US federal agency under the Department of Health and Human Services, whose main goal is to protect public health and safety through the control and prevention of disease.
A formal name for the disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, responsible for the 2019/2020 global pandemic.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): a place where people can be tested for the virus.

An informal name for the SARS-CoV-2 virus (also known as "novel coronavirus"), responsible for the 2019/2020 global pandemic of COVID-19 (the disease caused by the virus). Sometimes refers to the entire category of coronaviruses, of which SARS-CoV-2 is just one example.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): a mask covering the nose, mouth and/or eyes of the wearer, intended to protect the wearer from spreading or contracting pathogens.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): can be a person, such as a doctor, but also an organization, such as a hospital or insurance company.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): a person who works in healthcare, such as a doctor or therapist.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): the practice of cleaning one's hands, e.g. with water and soap, in order to get rid of the virus and other pathogens.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): the period of time between infection and the appearance of symptoms of the disease.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): the practice of separating sick people from healthy people to prevent the spread of disease.
In the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19): the practice of restricting the movement of healthy people who may have been exposed to the virus to see if they become ill.
In the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19): to restrict the movement of healthy people who may have been exposed to the virus to see if they become ill.

Short for "National Institutes of Health Agency": the primary US government agency responsible for biomedical and public health research; part of the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): being within a close distance (1-2m) of another person, not necessarily having actual physical contact. Close contact is one possible way for the virus to spread from person to person.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): the process of the virus spreading from person to person.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): cases of people infected with the virus which have resulted in the end of the infected person's life.
In the context of coronavirus (COVID-19): a place where people can be tested for the virus.
In the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19): to infect new people, in a particular area or globally.
A header for a set of five recommendations surfaced to users looking for coronavirus tips. See: https://www.google.com/search?q=coronavirus+tips&fbx=dothefive
A specialized agency of the United Nations that is concerned with world public health. Abbreviated as "WHO". See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization
Short for "World Health Organization": a specialized agency of the United Nations that is concerned with world public health. See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization
